text: The voiced bilabial nasal is a type of consonant. It is used in almost all spoken languages. The letter for this sound in the International Phonetic Alphabet is ⟨⟩. The X-SAMPA symbol for this sound is `⟨m⟩`. The English language has this sound, and it is the sound represented by "m" in map and rum. Nearly all languages contain this sound. A few languages (for example, Mohawk) do not often use this sound. == Features == == Examples == Language Word IPA Meaning Arabic Standard 'kitchens' Catalan 'mother' Chinese Cantonese / 'night' Mandarin / 'mother' Dutch 'mouth' English 'him' Finnish 'I' French 'to eat' Georgian 'three' Greek / 'clump' Hawaiian 'eye' Indonesian 'enter' Italian 'mamma' Japanese 乾杯/ 'a toast' Malay 'night' Malayalam 'shortage' Polish 'mass' Portuguese 'bush' Russian 'husband' Spanish 'cabin boy' Vietnamese 'salt' Zapotec Tilquiapan 'animal' ==References== Category:Consonants
title: Voiced bilabial nasal
